(2003) | Misc = }} "'''The Hell Song'''" is a song by Canadian [[Rock music|rock]] band [[Sum 41]]. The song was released in February 2003 as the second single of the band's album ''[[Does This Look Infected?]]''. "The Hell Song" was released to radio on February 18, 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.fmqb.com/Article.asp?id=16771|title=FMQB Airplay Archive: Modern Rock|publisher=Friday Morning Quarterback Album Report, Incorporated|accessdate=October 30, 2016}} The song was featured in the films ''[[American Wedding]]'' and ''[[Punk's Not Dead (2007 film)|Punk's Not Dead]]'' and in the video game ''[[Backyard Wrestling: Don't Try This at Home]]''. "The Hell Song" was certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA)]] on May 29, 2015.{{Certification Cite Ref|region=United States|type=single|title=The Hell Song|artist=Sum 41}} ==Background== Deryck Whibley, the lead vocalist of Sum 41, wrote "The Hell Song" after learning that one of his friends had contracted HIV.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1458709/20021114/sum_41.jhtml|title=Sum 41 Sober Up On Does This Look Infected?|publisher=[[MTV]]}} He said, "That song just came out in, like, half an hour when I just found out," Whibley said. "I wasn't even meaning to write about it, but for some reason that just came out right away".{{cite journal |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rg0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA11&dq=the+hell+song+sum+41+spreads+billboard&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjW6q3Up9jMAhXJ7RQKHb3GATEQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=the%20hell%20song%20sum%2041%20spreads%20billboard&f=false |title=Sum 41 Spreads 'Infected' |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |last=Whitmire |first=Margo |year=2002 |volume=114 |number=48 |ISSN=0006-2510 |publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media, Inc.]] |page=11}} ==Music video== The music video was of a concert with dolls and action figures, with Sum 41's faces on those "performing" in front of a [[Lite-Brite]] screen. They were joined with other action figures such as those of [[Snoop Dogg]], [[Eminem]], [[Ozzy Osbourne]] with his family, [[Marilyn Manson]], [[Korn]], [[Metallica]], [[Eddie the Head]], [[Gene Simmons]], [[Spice Girls]], [[Angus Young]], [[Jesus Christ]], [[Alice Cooper]], [[Destiny's Child]], [[George W. Bush]] and [[Ludacris]]. The dolls' obscene finger gestures and nudity are comically censored, which parodies real life. The video was directed by [[Marc Klasfeld]]. ==Track listing== ===UK release=== # The Hell Song (album version) # The Hell Song (radio edit) ===US release=== # The Hell Song (No-spit Intro) # The Hell Song (Spit Intro) ===Part 1=== # "The Hell Song" # "[[Over My Head (Better Off Dead)]]" (demo) # "My Direction" (demo) # "The Hell Song" (video) ===Part 2=== # "The Hell Song" (live) # "[[Still Waiting (Sum 41 song)|Still Waiting]]" (live) # "Rhthyms" (live) # "The Hell Song" (live) (video) All live tracks (on this CD) from Sound, London. ===7"=== A : # "The Hell Song" B : # "Still Waiting" (Live from Sound, London) ==Charts== {| class="wikitable" !Chart (2003-04) !Peak
position |- |Australian ARIA Singles Chart |align="center"|76 |- |Belgian Singles Chart (Flanders) |align="center"|59 |- |[[Canadian Singles Chart]] |align="center"|2 |- |Italy ([[Federation of the Italian Music Industry|FIMI]]){{cite web|url=http://www.hitparadeitalia.it/indici/per_interprete/ap.htm|title=Hit Parade Italia - Indice per Interprete: P|accessdate=July 6, 2012|publisher=Hit Parade Italia}} | style="text-align:center;"|37 |- |[[UK Singles Chart]] | align="center" |35 |- |U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Modern Rock Tracks]] |align="center"|13 |} ==Certifications== {{certification Table Top}} {{certification Table Entry|region=United States|artist=Sum 41|title=The Hell Song|award=Gold{{sup|{{Dagger}}}}|certyear=2015|relyear=2002|salesamount=500,000|type=single|}} {{Certification Table Bottom|format=3col|nounspecified=true}} {{small|{{sup|{{Dagger}}}} Since May 2013 RIAA certifications for digital singles include on-demand audio and/or video song streams in addition to downloads.{{cite news|url=https://www.riaa.com/newsitem.php?content_selector=riaa-news-gold-and-platinum&news_month_filter=5&news_year_filter=2013&id=C19496E7-CEC0-C453-D8A1-BD80E56E610F |title=RIAA Adds Digital Streams To Historic Gold & Platinum Awards|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|date=May 9, 2013|accessdate=May 9, 2013}}}} ==References== ==External links== *{{youtube|7pE8ReA5cn4|"The Hell Song" Official music video}} {{Sum 41 songs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hell Song, The}} [[Category:2003 singles]] [[Category:2002 songs]] [[Category:Songs about HIV/AIDS]] [[Category:Music videos directed by Marc Klasfeld]] [[Category:Sum 41 songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Greig Nori]] [[Category:Songs written by Deryck Whibley]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of musicians]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Jesus]] {{punk-song-stub}} {{2000s-single-stub}}

page.title: Timeline of events related to the South Thailand insurgency

revision.text:
{{See also|South Thailand insurgency|History of Thailand}} <!--safeguard for composite page--> {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}}
This article lists a chronology of events in the '''[[South Thailand insurgency]]''' from the 1960s. Most take place in the Muslim-majority, contested provinces of [[Narathiwat Province|Narathiwat]], [[Pattani Province|Pattani]], and [[Yala Province|Yala]] in the far south of Thailand bordering Muslim [[Malaysia]].
For earlier events see [[History of Thailand]].
{{TOC limit|3}}
==Timeline==
===1960–1998=== Although the conflict was carried out with less intensity, armed resistance in the 1960s and 1970s involved up to 1,500 insurgents.<ref name=KiwL/>
'''1960''': The [[Barisan Revolusi Nasional]] (BRN) was founded by Haji Abdul Karim in response to the introduction of a secular curriculum in Pattani's religious boarding schools.<ref name="RAND-2008">{{cite book|last1=Chalk|first1=Peter|title=The Malay-Muslim Insurgency in Southern Thailand; Understanding the Conflict's Evolving Dynamic|date=2008|publisher=RAND Corporation|location=Santa Monica|url=http://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/occasional_papers/2008/RAND_OP198.pdf|accessdate=12 March 2017|format=Occasional Paper|chapter=RAND Counterinsurgency Study-Paper 5}}</ref>
'''1968''': [[Patani United Liberation Organisation]] (PULO) was founded by Tengku Bira Kotanila (alias Kabir Abdul Rahman). PULO became the most powerful insurgent group during the 1960 – 2000 period of the war.<ref name=RAND-2008/>
''' 29 November 1975''': Thai marines allegedly murdered five Muslim youths in the [[Bacho District]] of Narathiwat Province. The government allegedly failed to conduct a proper investigation into the matter.<ref name=AmER>{{cite web|url=http://kms1.isn.ethz.ch/serviceengine/Files/ISN/10752/ipublicationdocument_singledocument/9e93edd5-3b11-4b7b-bc9d-59aa638320f2/en/098_southern_thailand.pdf |title=Insurgency, Not Jihad |work=Asia Report 98 |date=18 May 2005 |accessdate=6 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141208032106/http://kms1.isn.ethz.ch/serviceengine/Files/ISN/10752/ipublicationdocument_singledocument/9e93edd5-3b11-4b7b-bc9d-59aa638320f2/en/098_southern_thailand.pdf |archivedate=8 December 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
'''11 December 1975''': PULO organised mass protests in response to the event, which were joined by 70,000 Malay Muslims. A bomb was thrown into the crowd killing 12 and injuring at least 30 protesters. The attack was blamed on Buddhist extremists.<ref name=AmER/>
The government charged and imprisoned the perpetrators and launched an official inquiry and compensated the families of the victims. Despite the fact that the majority of the protesters demands were granted, the event led to an escalation of the insurgency.<ref name=AmER/>
'''June 1977''': Sabilillah (Path of God) bombed [[Don Mueang International Airport]] in [[Bangkok]]. In the aftermath of the bombing Sabilillah vanished into obscurity.<ref name=AmER/>
'''September 1977''': Black December 1902 members threw a bomb into a Thai royal ceremony. Five persons were killed and 47 wounded. The royal family managed to escape unharmed.<ref name=AmER/>
'''1977''': Security forces killed [[Barisan Nasional Pembebasan Patani|BNPP]] leader Tunku Yala Nasae.<ref name=AmER/>
* Renewed agitation began in the 1990s, led by Malay intellectuals influenced by revolutionary and [[Islamism|Islamist]] ideas from the [[Middle East]]. The BRN split into three rival factions, of which the most militant were the BRN Coordinate and the BRN Congress. The BRN Congress is regarded as the most active group, but there are several others, and competition between these militant groups has helped fuel the insurgency. It is believed that there is now a co-ordinating body called the [[Patani United Liberation Organisation]] (Dewan Pembebasan Pattani or PULO), although little is known about the composition or leadership of the various groups.
'''1993''': The [[Patani United Liberation Organisation|New PULO]], a dissident faction of the original PULO, was established by Arrong Moo-reng and Hayi Abdul Rohman Bazo.<ref name=RAND-2008/>
'''1995''': Nasoree Saesang founded the [[Gerakan Mujahidin Islam Patani|GMIP]].<ref name=AmER/>
'''August 1996''': Thirty-six schools were torched in Yala, Pattani, and Narathiwat allegedly by members of the New PULO faction,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/home/20-schools-torched-arsenal-raided-91357.html |title=unk |publisher= |accessdate=13 May 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141217095658/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/home/20-schools-torched-arsenal-raided-91357.html |archivedate=17 December 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> reportedly a dissident faction of the original PULO established by Arrong Moo-reng and Hayi Abdul Rohman Bazo.<ref name=RAND-2008/> The Thai Interior Ministry and Thai Military Intelligence reported that New PULO used unemployed youth and young drug addicts to carry out its terrorist missions.<ref name="RG&AA">[[Rohan Gunaratna]] & Arabinda Acharya , ''The Terrorist Threat from Thailand: Jihad Or Quest for Justice?''</ref>
'''1997''': Members of the [[Barisan Revolusi Nasional Melayu Patani]] (BRN), [[Patani United Liberation Organisation|PULO]] and the [[Patani United Liberation Organisation|New PULO]] established the United Mujahideen Front of Pattani to improve co-ordination between rebel factions.<ref name=RAND-2008/>
'''August 1997''': [[Bersatu]] launched an operation code named "Falling Leaves". Between August 1997 and January 1998, 33 separate attacks took place resulting in nine deaths.<ref name=AmER/>
'''January 1998''': Malaysia and Thailand launched a joint operation code named "Pitak Tai" to crack down on insurgent outfits.<ref name="RG&AA"/> Malaysian authorities arrested New PULO's leader,Abdul Rohman Bazo, its military chief, Haji Daoh Thanam, and Bazo's senior assistant, Haji Mae Yala in Kedah, as well as PULO's military commander, Haji Sama-ae Thanam, in [[Kuala Lumpur]], later handing them to Thai authorities.<ref name=AmER/> The Thai government also encouraged local people to monitor the movements of drug traffickers and, as a result, the tough policy on drugs deprived PULO of recruits for its acts of terror.<ref name="RG&AA"/>
===1999–2002=== * Following the [[September 11 attacks|11 September 2001 attacks]] in the United States, leaflets calling for Holy War and support for [[Osama bin Laden]] were distributed in Yala by militants.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.jamestown.org/single/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=893#.VHxpB9JSVqk|title=A Breakdown of Southern Thailand's Insurgent Groups|journal=Terrorism Monitor|volume=4|issue=17|author=Zachary Abuza|publisher=The Jamestown Foundation|date=2006-09-08|accessdate=13 May 2016}}</ref>
'''24 December 2001''': Insurgents launched a number of attacks on police posts in the three provinces. Five police and one defence volunteer were killed.<ref name=KiwL>{{cite web|url=http://www.law.unimelb.edu.au/files/dmfile/funstonfinalforwebsite2.pdf |title=Conflict in Southern Thailand |work=Melbourne Law School Paper |date=2008 |accessdate=6 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query.php?url=http://www.law.unimelb.edu.au/files/dmfile/funstonfinalforwebsite2.pdf |archivedate=11 August 2006 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
* The Thai National Intelligence Agency estimated that fewer than 1,000 armed militants were taking part in the conflict as of 2001.<ref name=AmER/> In that year, the Thai Ministry of Interior estimated that 50 insurgency-related incidents had occurred.<ref name=AmER/> By 2002, 75 insurgency-linked attacks had killed 50 police and army personnel.<ref name=RAND-2008/>
===2003=== * In 2003, officials counted 149 incidents. The mounting scale and sophistication of the insurgency eventually prompted the government into a recognition that there was a serious issue in the southern provinces.<ref name=RAND-2008/>
===2004=== '''4 January''': An escalation of the violence in the southern border provinces of Yala, Pattani, and Narathiwat is reckoned to have begun on 4 January 2004 with the raiding of a Thai Army depot.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Phongsutthirak|first1=Thitinan|title=Conflict and Terrorism in Southern Thailand (review)|journal=Contemporary Southeast Asia: A Journal of International and Strategic Affairs|date=April 2006|volume=28|issue=1|pages=160–163|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/206156|accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref> Unidentified gunmen raided an army ammunition depot in [[Narathiwat Province]] in the early morning, and made off with over 400 rifles and ammunition.<ref name=RAND-2008/>
'''5 January''': Two policemen were killed while attempting to defuse a bomb outside a shopping mall in Pattani. A third policeman was injured in bomb blast that occurred in a nearby park. Two more bombs were successfully defused in nearby areas. Prime minister [[Thaksin Shinawatra]] declared martial law in the provinces of Narathiwat, Pattani, and Yala.<ref name=GS-2001-2004>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/thailand2-01.htm|title=Thailand Islamic Insurgency, 2001-2004 |work=Global Security|date=|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref>
'''22 January''': Rebels killed a Buddhist monk.<ref name=GS-2001-2004/>
'''12 March''': [[Somchai Neelapaijit]], a Thai-Muslim lawyer and human rights activist, was abducted in [[Bang Kapi District|Ramkhamhaeng]], Bangkok. He represented Muslim defendants, who said they had been tortured, in terrorism cases. He was never seen again.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Duggleby |first1=Luke|title=Murdered After Defending Thailand's Environment|url=https://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2016/05/22/blogs/murdered-after-defending-thailands-environment/s/22thailandmydans-slide-ICZJ.html|format=Photo essay|page=3|accessdate=13 March 2017|work=New York Times|agency=Redux|date=2016-05-22}}</ref>
'''28 March''': A bomb planted by insurgents injured 29 people, including 10 Malaysian tourists.<ref name=GS-2001-2004/>
'''30 March''': Masked men raided a quarry in the Yala District, stealing a total of 1.6 tonnes of [[ammonium nitrate]], 56 sticks of dynamite, and 176 detonators.<ref name=RAND-2008/>
'''23 April''': Militants killed an army officer and set fire to 50 public buildings in all 13 districts of Narathiwat Province.<ref name=GS-2001-2004/>
'''28 April''': Militants launched a string of attacks on armouries and army positions in Pattani, Yala, and Songkhla. One-hundred eight rebels were killed in the aftermath of the attacks.<ref name=RAND-2008/>
'''10 June''': Militants killed a security guard outside a government school and seized weapons from other security personnel who were inside.<ref name=GS-2001-2004/>
'''25 October''': Seventy-eight persons were killed by Thai police in the aftermath of a riot over the detentions of Muslims suspected of giving weapons to Islamic separatists. Over 1,300 people were detained in the incident.<ref name=GS-2001-2004/>
'''28 October''': An [[Improvised explosive device|IED]] detonated outside a bar, killing two persons and injuring 21.<ref name=GS-2001-2004/>
'''2 November''': A Buddhist official was beheaded by suspected Muslim insurgents.<ref name=GS-2001-2004/>
'''4 November''': Nine persons were killed including two police.<ref name=GS-2001-2004/>
'''7 November''': The [[Defence Minister]] of Thailand said that there had been more than 700 casualties in south Thailand since the unrest began in January. Many murders involved shooting and [[decapitation]]. During 2004, insurgents began to sow fear in attacks by beheading [[Buddhists]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/06/15/idUSBKK434239|title=Thai Buddhist beheaded, another shot in Muslim south|agency=Reuters|date=2009-06-15|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
'''13 November''': One man was killed and at least 13 people injured when five bomb blasts occurred in various parts of the region.<ref name=GS-2001-2004/>
'''5 December''': Thailand airdropped nearly 100 million origami cranes over the southern regions of the country in an effort to bring peace. Militants respond with series of bombings the following day.<ref name=GS-2001-2004/>
* A total of 400 people were killed in over 1,000 incidents during 2004.<ref name=KiwL/><ref name=AmER/>
===2005=== '''17 February''': A bomb exploded near a tourist hotel in the town of [[Sungai Kolok]], killing five persons and wounding over 40. Four persons were killed in other incidents.<ref name=GS-2005-2006>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/thailand2-05.htm|title=Thailand Islamic Insurgency, 2005-2006 |publisher=Global Security|date=|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref>
'''3 April''': A [[2005 Songkhla bombings|series of bomb attacks]] in [[Songkhla Province|Songkhla]] killed two people and leaving 66 injured. The bombings marked the beginning of attacks against ethnic Thai–Chinese–owned businesses who were considered Thaksin supporters and against southern Thailand independence as a Muslim state.
'''14 July''': A major attack was launched on the provincial capital of [[Yala, Thailand|Yala city]]. Sixty militants targeted an area near a hotel, the railway station, two [[convenience store]]s and a restaurant roaming the streets using guns, fire-bombs, and explosives.<ref name=OODAL>{{cite web|url=http://www.terrorism.com/2014/04/23/at-least-60-thai-muslims-attack-yala-city/ |title=404 Error |work=OODA Loop |accessdate=13 May 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150124070851/http://www.terrorism.com/2014/04/23/at-least-60-thai-muslims-attack-yala-city/ |archivedate=24 January 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
'''18 July''': Two militants entered a teashop, shot Lek Pongpla, a Buddhist cloth vendor, [[Beheading in Islamism|beheaded him]] and left the head outside of the shop.<ref name=OODAL/>
'''19 July''': The Thai Prime Minister enacted the "emergency powers law" to manage the three troubled states giving himself sweeping powers to direct military operations, suspend [[civil liberties]], and [[Censorship|censor]] the press. Several human rights organisations and local press expressed their concerns that these new powers might be used to violate civil liberty rights. However, the emergency decree was highly popular, with 72 percent of Bangkok residents and 86 percent of people in the three southern provinces supporting it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abacpoll.au.edu/in_news/2549/bangkokpost100706.pdf |title=Strategy based on hopelessness|date=2006-07-10|accessdate=2 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801084959/http://www.abacpoll.au.edu/in_news/2549/bangkokpost100706.pdf |archivedate=1 August 2013 }}</ref> Nevertheless, the insurgency escalated further.
'''31 August''': Three bombs exploded almost simultaneously.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://today.reuters.com/News/CrisesArticle.aspx?storyId=BKK66334 |accessdate=2 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |title=Three bombs hit Thai Muslim south, injure 15|agency=Reuters|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060312171259/http://today.reuters.com/News/CrisesArticle.aspx?storyId=BKK66334|date=31 August 2005|archivedate=12 March 2006 }}</ref> Subsequently, 131 civilians from the south fled to neighbouring Malaysia seeking refuge from the Thai authorities. Thailand immediately accused the refugees of being insurgents and demanded that they be returned, sparking a diplomatic spat. Currently, the people are still in Malaysia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://today.reuters.com/News/CrisesArticle.aspx?storyId=KLR53697|title=Malaysia, Thailand swap barbs over Muslim unrest |date= 17 October 2005|accessdate=2 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060317233757/http://today.reuters.com/News/CrisesArticle.aspx?storyId=KLR53697 |archivedate=17 March 2006 }}</ref> Thailand, suspecting that insurgents may also have fled with the refugees, has asked Malaysia to return these Thai citizens but Malaysia has refused on humanitarian grounds.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4208094.stm | work=BBC News | title=Malaysia risks row with Thailand | date=2 September 2005 | accessdate=23 May 2010}}</ref>
'''16 October''': A group of 20 separatists attacked a Buddhist monastery, killing three. An extended state of emergency was announced in the three southern provinces plagued by the insurgency. The announcement sparked a large scale guerrilla raid on 60 targets, in which at least seven persons were killed and 90 weapons were stolen.<ref name=GS-2005-2006/>
'''16 November''': Separatists killed nine civilians and injured nine others.<ref name=GS-2005-2006/>
* A total of 500 people were killed during 2005.<ref name=KiwL/>
===2006=== * A brief lull in the insurgency followed the [[September 2006 Thailand coup|19 September 2006 coup]] that overthrew the government of Premier [[Thaksin Shinawatra]]. As Army Commander [[Sonthi Boonyaratkalin]] settled into his role as head of the junta, violence resumed. {{As of|2006|9}}, more than 1,400 people had died in less than three years of southern violence. Most were innocent bystanders, both Buddhists and Muslims.
'''7 January''': Four suspected militants fatally shot two border-police at a weekend market in Yala Province.{{CN|date=March 2017}} Three others were killed in separate attacks on the same day.{{CN|date=March 2017}}
'''10 May''': A bomb exploded at a tea shop killing at least three persons and injuring more than a dozen.<ref name=GS-2005-2006/>
'''15 June''': During the [[60th anniversary of the accession of Bhumibol Adulyadej]] to the Thai throne, well-coordinated bomb-attacks against at least 40 government and official buildings occurred. Two police officials died and 11 others were injured. Experts say that the bomb attacks were a message to the Thai authorities, rather than an attempt to do real damage, as the bombs were loaded with small amounts of explosives. Had the devices been larger, the casualties and injuries would have been notably greater. The Thai media was late in reporting the incident, only doing so after the [[BBC]] and other international news services had announced it.{{CN|date=March 2017}}
'''18 June''': Mass graves of about 300 migrant workers were found in southern Thailand.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/home/Migrant-workers-in-300-unmarked-graves-in-Thai-sou-30005107.html |title=Migrant workers in 300 unmarked graves in Thai south |work=The Nation |accessdate=14 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022034927/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/home/Migrant-workers-in-300-unmarked-graves-in-Thai-sou-30005107.html |archivedate=22 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>[http://www.bangkokpost.com/breaking_news/breakingnews.php?id=99594 Breakingnews]{{Dead link|date=February 2011}}</ref>
'''27 June''': Seven persons including five security personnel were killed in separatist attacks.<ref name=GS-2005-2006/>
'''31 August''': Twenty-two commercial banks were simultaneously bombed in Yala Province, killing a retired military officer and wounding 24 people. Afterwards, Army chief [[Sonthi Boonyaratglin]] announced that he would break with government policy and negotiate with the leaders of the insurgency. However, he noted that "We still don't know who is the real head of the militants we are fighting with."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nationmultimedia.com/2006/09/02/headlines/headlines_30012623.php |title=Sonthi calls for talks |work=The Nation |date= |accessdate=19 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110518010052/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/09/02/headlines/headlines_30012623.php |archivedate=18 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In a press conference the next day, he slammed the government for political interference, and asked that the government "Free the military and let it do the job."<ref>[http://bangkokpost.net/News/02Sep2006_news01.php]{{Dead link|date=February 2010}}</ref> By 16 September, the army admitted that it still wasn't sure who to negotiate with.<ref>''Bangkok Post'', [http://bangkokpost.net/News/19Sep2006_news03.php Deep South: Army wants peace talks but unsure who with], 19 September 2006 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129091756/http://bangkokpost.net/News/19Sep2006_news03.php |date=29 January 2016 }}</ref>
'''September''': Army Commander [[Sonthi Boonyaratkalin]] was granted an extraordinary increase in executive powers to combat the unrest.<ref name="CEN-20060908">{{cite news|title=Army commander's powers to rise: Thai Deputy PM|url=http://en.ce.cn/World/Asia-Pacific/200609/08/t20060908_8479858.shtml|accessdate=12 March 2017|work=China Economic Net|agency=Xinhuanet|date=2006-09-08}}</ref>
'''16 September''': Six remotely detonated motorcycle bombs simultaneously exploded in the [[2006 Hat Yai bombings]], killing four people and wounding more than sixty. A Canadian and a Malaysian were among the dead.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/5352540.stm | work=BBC News|title=Bombs explode in south Thailand|date=16 September 2006|accessdate=23 May 2010}}</ref>
'''21 September''': Two villagers were shot in Yala, killing one and wounding another.<ref>{{th icon}} ''Thai Rath'', [http://www.thairath.co.th/online.php?section=newsthairathonline&content=20428 โจรฉวยโอกาสช่วงรัฐประหาร ยิงชาวบ้านยะลาตาย1เจ็บ1], 21 September 2006 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206131241/http://www.thairath.co.th/online.php?section=newsthairathonline&content=20428 |date=6 December 2008 }}</ref>
'''23 September''': Four police were injured in a bus stop explosion in Pattani. The bus stop was on a road that would be passed by the motorcade of Crown Prince [[Maha Vajiralongkorn]] later that afternoon.<ref>Thai Public Relations Department, [http://thainews.prd.go.th/newsenglish/previewnews.php?news_id=254909230026&news_headline=4 4 policemen injured in an explosion in Pattani] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090115011518/http://thainews.prd.go.th/newsenglish/previewnews.php?news_id=254909230026&news_headline=4 |date=15 January 2009 }}, 23 September 2006</ref><!--Double check that date--><ref>''The Nation'', [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30014468 4 policemen injured in bus stop explosion in Pattani] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090909151233/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30014468 |date=9 September 2009 }}</ref>
'''25 September''': Two police stations and a military outpost were attacked by 30 gunmen in a coordinated series of attacks in Yala, leaving two dead and one injured.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/09/27/national/national_30014759.php Two die as police, military outposts attacked in Yala], 27 September 2006</ref>
'''27 September''': Gunmen killed a grocer and two of his customers in [[Amphoe Mueang Yala|Mueang Yala District]] of Yala Province and a traveller on the bus from [[Amphoe Panare|Panare District]] to [[Amphoe Mayo|Mayo District]] of Pattani.<ref>''The Bangkok Post'', [http://bangkokpost.net/News/28Sep2006_news04.php Gunmen kill 3 in Yala, and another in Pattani]{{Dead link|date=February 2010}}, 28 September 2006</ref>
'''28 September''': A teacher protection unit in [[Su-ngai Padi District]] of Narathiwat Province was ambushed by a bomb attack, seriously injuring four soldiers and killing one.<ref>[http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30014867] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090909100739/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30014867|date=9 September 2009}}</ref>
'''18 October''': Suspected Muslim guerrillas raided an army base, killing one soldier and wounding four others.<ref name=GS-2005-2006/>
'''4 November''': Three schools burned to the ground and a person received a gunshot wound.<ref>''BBC'' [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/6116220.stm Thailand 'rebels' attack schools]. 4 November 2006.</ref>
'''5 November''': A bomb blast killed two soldiers and injured three others. Four persons were killed and six wounded in a series of shootings and bomb blasts.<ref name=GS-2005-2006/>
'''9 November''': Eight car and motorcycle showrooms were simultaneously bombed in Yala, injuring 13. Almost all gold shops in Mueang District closed down for fear of their safety. Commercial banks remained open, but with tightened security.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/2006/11/09/headlines/headlines_30018512.php Car and motorcycle showrooms bombed in Yala] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312201543/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/11/09/headlines/headlines_30018512.php |date=12 March 2017 }}, 9 November 2006</ref>
* From January 2004 to October 2006, 1,815 people were killed and 2,729 were wounded in the insurgency.<ref>''Bangkok Post'', [http://bangkokpost.net/breaking_news/breakingnews.php?id=114150 Death toll in South reaches 1,800], 11 November 2006 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090113224438/http://bangkokpost.net/breaking_news/breakingnews.php?id=114150 |date=13 January 2009 }}</ref> Despite the renewed violence, a post-coup opinion poll found that southerners had become the happiest people of Thailand.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/2006/11/06/national/national_30018161.php Southerners now the happiest of Thais] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314112203/http://nationmultimedia.com/2006/11/06/national/national_30018161.php |date=14 March 2012 }}, 6 November 2006</ref>
'''15 November''': Militants shot dead three persons in separate drive-by shootings. One soldier was also wounded in a bomb blast.<ref name=GS-2005-2006/>
'''17 November''': Three bomb explosions killed one person and wounded at least 30 others.<ref name=GS-2005-2006/>
'''22 November''': [[Wan Kadir Che Wan]], leader of [[Bersatu]], one of the southern insurgent groups, told Al Jazeera television that the [[Al-Qaeda]]-linked [[Jemaah Islamiyah]] (JI) terrorist network was helping local insurgents stage attacks in Thailand.<ref>AFP, [https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20061122/wl_asia_afp/thailandsouthunrest_061122154531 Thai rebel leader says JI aiding guerrillas in Muslim south]{{Dead link|date=February 2010}}, 22 November 2006</ref>
'''27 November''': After all schools in Pattani announced indefinite shutdown, teachers in Yala and Narathiwat followed suit and closed down schools in the two provinces indefinitely for safety. The decision in Pattani was made after a series of arson attacks against schools and the fatal shooting of two schoolteachers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/11/27/headlines/headlines_30020090.php|title=Schools in Narathiwat and Yala to be closed indefinitely|work=The Nation|accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref> In Yala, Pattani, and Narathiwat Provinces over 1,000 schools were shut down.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30020082 All schools in restive south to be closed], 27 November 2006 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080606205823/http://nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30020082 |date=6 June 2008 }}</ref><ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/2006/11/28/national/national_30020154.php Over 1,000 schools closed] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303183826/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/11/28/national/national_30020154.php |date=3 March 2016 }}, 28 November 2006</ref>
'''9 December''': A police informant was killed in a drive-by shooting.<ref name=GS-2005-2006/>
'''29 December''': Two teachers were shot and burned to death.<ref name=GS-2005-2006/>
'''31 December''': Nine bomb blasts occurred in [[Bangkok]] on New Year's Eve, killing three persons and injuring 38. New Year's Eve celebrations were cancelled.<ref name=GS-2005-2006/>
===2007=== Despite conciliatory gestures from the junta, the insurgency continued and intensified. The death toll, 1,400 at the time of the coup, increased to 2,579 by mid-September 2007.<ref name="Janes.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.janes.com/news/security/countryrisk/jiaa/jiaa071119_1_n.shtml |title=Mid-November 2007 update on the insurgency |publisher=Janes |date=19 November 2007 |accessdate=3 November 2011}}</ref>
From '''January 2004 to 21 June 2007''', the south witnessed 6,850 violent incidents related to the insurgency. At least 2,303 people were killed and more than 6,000 injured in that time, according to [[Srisompob Jitpiromsri]] of Prince of Songkhla University's Pattani campus.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30037473 Sweep-up operation in Yala], 21 June 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929121601/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30037473 |date=29 September 2007 }}</ref>
[[CDRM|Junta]] chairman Sonthi Boonyaratglin announced that the Southern Border Provinces Administrative Centre (SBPAC) and the Civilian-Police-Military Task Force (CPM) 43 would be revived. Sonthi said the army-led multi-agency Southern Border Provinces Peace Building Command would be dissolved and its troops would come under CPM 43, which would operate in parallel with the SBPAC. The SBPAC and CPM 43 had been dissolved in mid-2001 by former Premier Thaksin Shinawatra. Before that, CPM 43 was under the directive of the SBPAC. Sonthi also made himself head of the [[Internal Security Operations Command]] (ISOC). Previously, ISOC had been headed by the prime minister.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/2006/10/18/politics/politics_30016481.php Southern groups to be revived] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303195721/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/10/18/politics/politics_30016481.php |date=3 March 2016 }}, 18 October 2006</ref>
ISOC was given 5.9 billion [[Thai baht|baht]] in funding for [[fiscal year]] 2007. By May 2007, General Sonthi asked the government for an additional emergency budget of two billion baht for ISOC, as the normal budget was running out. The money was under the "secret budget" category, which meant that state officials could spend it without having to account for it.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/05/15/national/national_30034238.php Sonthi seeks Bt2 bn for ISOC], 15 May 2007</ref>
'''14 January''': A [[rubber tapper]] named Pin Khotchathin was [[behead]]ed in [[Yala Province|Yala]]. His head was found at a [[Para rubber tree|rubber plantation]] in Tambon Tasae in Yala's [[Amphoe Mueang Yala|Mueang district]] five metres from his body.<ref>{{Cite news| title=Rubber tapper beheaded as 3 die in Yala attacks | work=Bangkok Post | date=15 January 2007 | url=http://thailandpost.blogspot.com/2007/01/rubber-tapper-beheaded-as-3-die-in.html}}</ref> It was the 22nd murder to feature a beheading since May 2004, although the militants were not always successful in removing their victim's head.<ref>{{Cite news| title= Militants behead 25th southern victim | work= Bangkok Post | url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/topstories/topstories.php?id=117271 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20120724195937/http://www.bangkokpost.com/topstories/topstories.php?id=117271 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=24 July 2012 | date=6 March 2007}}</ref> A handwritten note was left near Pin's head warning of further bloodshed to avenge what the attackers, calling themselves ''Pattani Warriors,'' claimed was a case of authorities killing [[separatist]] members.
Facing rising violence, Prime Minister Surayud Chulanont accused Muslim junta chief [[Sonthi Boonyaratkalin]] of failing to do enough to curb the insurgency.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30026735 PM blames junta leader for worsening unrest], 13 February 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070305062928/http://nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30026735 |date=5 March 2007 }}</ref>
'''18 February''': A series of bombings and arson attacks began in [[Narathiwat]], [[Yala Province|Yala]], and [[Pattani]], and [[Songkhla]] Provinces. Six people were killed and over 50 were injured.<ref>Michael Jerryson, Buddhist Fury (New York: Oxford University Press, 2011), 167 and 229.</ref>
Violence escalated though in the months following the implementation of the junta's "hearts and minds" campaign. The monthly death toll increased by 30 percent in the five months after the coup compared to the five months before the coup.<ref name="militias">''International Herald Tribune'', [http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/03/19/news/thai.php Use of militias rising in southern Thailand], 19 March 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070322183316/http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/03/19/news/thai.php |date=22 March 2007 }}</ref> Insurgents targeted Princess [[Sirindhorn]] by placing a bomb near her helicopter's landing pad.<ref>Zachary Abuza, [http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20070214142657/http://counterterrorismblog.org/2007/02/trends_in_thailands_insurgency.php Trends in Thailand's Insurgency in Early 2007], 7 February 2007</ref> A senior aide to Queen [[Sirikit]], Thanpuying [[Viriya Chavakul]], was injured and narrowly escaped death when gunmen attacked her vehicle convoy on 21 February 2007 in Yala.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/2007/02/22/headlines/headlines_30027553.php 22 February 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128204351/http://nationmultimedia.com/2007/02/22/headlines/headlines_30027553.php |date=28 January 2013 }}</ref> She later criticised the government for rotating troops too often, preventing them from building bonds with locals. She also made note of troops' lack of communications equipment and bulletproof vests.<ref>''Bangkok Post'', [http://pages.citebite.com/o1v1j4d5a8edw Queen's aide: Troops rotated too often], 23 February 2007</ref>
After an official visit to Thailand, Malaysian Prime Minister [[Abdullah Ahmad Badawi]] volunteered to act as a mediator in arranging talks between insurgents and Thai authorities. Foreign Minister [[Nitya Pibulsonggram]] rejected the offer.<ref>''Bangkok Post'', [http://bangkokpost.net/topstories/topstories.php?id=116810 Government turns away Malaysia mediation offer], 15 February 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071028222110/http://bangkokpost.net/topstories/topstories.php?id=116810 |date=28 October 2007 }}</ref>
During the [[Chinese New Year]] weekend (from the evening of 18 February 2007 to the afternoon of 19 February 2007), insurgents [[2007 South Thailand bombings|executed 38 bombing attacks, 26 cases of arson, and seven ambushes]]. The bombings targeted hotels, karaoke bars, power grids and commercial sites. Two public schools were torched. Three people were arrested.<ref>''New York Times'', [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/19/world/asia/19thailand.html?ref=asia South of Thailand Is Rocked by 28 Bombs], 19 February 2007</ref><ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/2007/02/21/national/national_30027420.php Three arrested over weekend attacks] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303222156/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/02/21/national/national_30027420.php |date=3 March 2016 }}, 21 February 2007</ref> Junta chief Sonthi and Interior Minister Aree Wongsearaya admitted that they knew in advance that attacks were going to take place.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/2007/02/20/politics/politics_30027306.php Army's admissions not so clever] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312200502/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/02/20/politics/politics_30027306.php |date=12 March 2017 }}, 20 February 2007</ref> Aree later admitted that the government's southern strategy was flawed.<ref>''Bangkok Post'', [http://pages.citebite.com/o1s1t2d8g7hhp Aree says South strategy flawed], 20 February 2007</ref>
'''21 February''': In their most significant act of economic terrorism and arson to date, insurgents burned down the Southland Rubber warehouse in Yala, destroying 5,000 tons of rubber worth approximately 400 million baht and engulfing Yala city in a dense cloud of black smoke for 12 hours. Thirty fire trucks fought to control the flames in the largest rubber warehouse in the deep south. Spikes were scattered on the road leading to the warehouse to slow emergency workers. No casualties were reported.<ref>''Bangkok Post'', [http://pages.citebite.com/w1t1s3q2s2uxk Extremist arson burns 400 million baht of rubber], 21 February 2007</ref>
'''March''': The junta's top security advisor admitted that insurgents imported their techniques from Al-Qaeda and the Taliban and were motivated by not only by nationalist reasons, like previous generations of insurgents, but religious extremism as well.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30029886 Thai militants adopting Al-Qaeda tactics: general], 22 March 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070326104033/http://nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30029886 |date=26 March 2007 }}</ref><ref>''Bangkok Post'', [http://pages.citebite.com/g1w4a0a6y2ssu Southern extremists learning from bin Laden], 22 March 2007</ref> However, it noted that it still did not know who was behind the insurgency.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30030479 Muslim rebels infiltrate villages: Thai junta leader], 28 March 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070401210104/http://nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30030479 |date=1 April 2007 }}</ref>
To protect the Buddhist minority from violence, the Internal Security Operations Command produced [[Jatukham Rammathep]] amulets for public distribution. The renowned animist amulets were believed by some to have magical powers to protect their holders from violence and large sums were generally paid for them. The plan was developed by Colonel Manas Khongpan, deputy director of the ISOC in [[Yala Province]].<ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/2007/03/14/national/national_30029259.php Amulets to 'help protect' Buddhists in South] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303175605/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/03/14/national/national_30029259.php |date=3 March 2016 }}, 14 March 2007</ref>
In March 2007, Queen [[Sirikit]] vowed to protect people of all religions in the south, and initiated weapons training programmes for locals, particularly teachers. Sirikit's deputy aide-de-camp Napol Boonthap said that the government should review its strategy and not only use a conciliatory approach towards the insurgents. "Legal action must also be taken against the wrongdoers to show we mean business," he said.<ref name="Queen" />
'''14 March''': Eight commuters from [[Betong, Betong|Betong]] to [[Hat Yai]] were executed after their van was stopped by insurgents. A roadside bomb delayed rangers stationed nearby in their efforts to reach the site.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/2007/03/15/headlines/headlines_30029344.php Massacre in Yala] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303222903/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/03/15/headlines/headlines_30029344.php |date=3 March 2016 }}, 15 March 2007</ref> A Pattani United Liberation Organisation (PULO) executive blamed a portion of the violence directly on [[Thahan Phran|paramilitary rangers]] who instigated violence and then blamed insurgents for their deeds.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/2007/03/16/headlines/headlines_30029455.php Soldiers help fan unrest in Thai south: separatists] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312201350/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/03/16/headlines/headlines_30029455.php |date=12 March 2017 }}, 16 March 2007</ref>
Crown Prince [[Vajiralongkorn]]'s motorcade was again targeted by a bombing in March 2007. A local police team found the bomb before it could explode.<ref name="Queen">''Bangkok Post'', [http://pages.citebite.com/j1p3a7e2t4rry Queen vows to protect southerners], 18 March 2007</ref>
'''April''': Junta chief Sonthi rejected a US offer to help train Thai forces to quell the insurgency. Sonthi continued to deny that international terrorists operate in the south.<ref>CNN, [http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/asiapcf/04/19/thailand.south.ap/ Thailand rejects U.S. help to quell insurgency], 19 April 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070505065120/http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/asiapcf/04/19/thailand.south.ap/ |date=5 May 2007 }}</ref>
'''9 April''': A pick-up truck carrying students and other passengers returning from a funeral was shot upon, killing two 12-year-old boys and two other 25-year-old university students. The funeral was for the Khuen Bang Lang tambon administration organisation chief, who was shot dead hours earlier the same day. The military initially claimed that insurgents were behind the shooting. It later admitted that [[Village Scouts|village defence volunteers]] attacked, after allegedly being "provoked" by insurgent sympathisers on the truck. Several hundred angry villagers staged protests against the shooting, demanding the government take action against those responsible.<ref>''Bangkok Post'', [http://pages.citebite.com/b1x5v2c1t1ary Army admits southern killings], 11 April 2007</ref>
'''13 April''': Protests after a mistaken shooting by security forces. Thai soldiers in Pattani shot and killed three Muslim teenagers. The soldiers, who were dispatched to investigate the torching of four mobile-phone relay outlets, opened fire on a group of teenagers when the soldiers thought the teenagers were charging at them. Locals reported that the teenagers were playing tag on the road near a weekly open market near where the soldiers were investigating. Three teenagers, aged 13 to 15 years, were killed and two others were injured. Local army commander Colonel Wanchai Paungkhumsa initially said the soldiers had acted in self-defense, saying that gunshots were fired from where a teenager was standing. Residents ended their protest after reaching a series of agreements with Pattani Governor Panu Uthairath over the shooting. The military agreed to investigate the shootings, and if it was a negligent act, soldiers would be faced criminal charges, be transferred out of the area, and an apology would be given to locals.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/04/15/headlines/headlines_30031903.php Protest ends after assurances], 15 April 2007</ref>
'''May''': Sonthi started withdrawing troops from the south, replacing them with territorial defence volunteers. He did not say why the regular army was to be reduced in the south.<ref>''Bangkok Post'', [http://pages.citebite.com/p1p6g8x1q5ijh Some troops to pull out of South], 12 May 2007</ref>
'''14 May''': Separatist insurgents shot dead a Thai-Buddhist couple working as fruit pickers in the majority-Muslim area of Bannang Sata, Yala Province and injured their three-year-old daughter. After gunning down Praphan Ponlarak, 36, and his wife Chaddakan, the assailants decapitated Praphan, making him the 29th victim to be beheaded in Thailand's south.<ref>[http://www.news24.com/News24/World/News/0,,2-10-1462_2113011,00.html Insurgents behead Buddhist], 15 April 2007 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001000035/http://www.news24.com/News24/World/News/0%2C%2C2-10-1462_2113011%2C00.html |date=1 October 2007 }}</ref>
Violence continued with a noted trend towards targeting soldiers and policemen, particularly after the militants' actions were criticised by [[Ekmeleddin Ihsanoglu]], secretary-general of the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]].<ref>''The Straits Times'', Thai militants targeting security forces now, 12 May 2007</ref> On 9 May 2007, the army saw its worse casualty in a single incident in years, when seven soldiers were killed in a roadside bombing incident.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/05/10/headlines/headlines_30033838.php Seven killed in brutal attack], 10 May 2007</ref> Two policemen were shot dead and their bodies burnt in another attack on 11 May 2007,<ref>''Bangkok Post'', [http://www.bangkokpost.com/News/12May2007_news05.php Two police killed in broad daylight raid], 12 May 2007 {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>[[Channel NewsAsia]], [http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/275633/1/.html Militants kill, burn policemen in Thai south], 12 May 2007</ref> which the authorities suspect were conducted by the same group which killed the soldiers.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/05/13/national/national_30034085.php Same gang blamed for two attacks], 13 May 2007</ref> Another 11 soldiers were killed on 31 May 2007 in similar style to the incident on 9 May.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/06/01/headlines/headlines_30035764.php Death toll of Thursday attacks is 21: army spokesman], 1 June 2007</ref>
Between 27 May and 29 May 2007, several concerted bombings occurred, both in Hat Yai downtown in front of markets, shops and hotels, and also in Saba Yoi, altogether killing more than four people and injuring over 20. The attacks targeted Chinese-Thai, who consider them 'Jews of the Far East' because they are barred from the Thai civil service and are mainly traders.<ref>[http://etna.mcot.net/query.php?nid=29637 Third day of bombings rattles Hat Yai]. 29 May (TNA) {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040825153017/http://etna.mcot.net/query.php?nid=29637 |date=25 August 2004 }}</ref>
'''July''': Former Fourth Army chief Harn Leelanont criticised the junta's reconciliation policy in the South, saying it left security personnel incapable of containing the violence. He claimed that it left officials and innocent people as sitting ducks to be picked off by militants.<ref>''Bangkok Post'', [http://pages.citebite.com/f1k9x3p2t6adp Reconciliation not working, general says], 7 July 2007</ref>
The military junta went on a massive spending spree, buying new weaponry and a dozen [[fighter jets]] from [[Sweden]], saying it needed the hardware to battle the insurgency.<ref>AFP, [http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gHYaoq-uPXBWrI79BO2qUlAJKsUg Muslim crucified, two Buddhists beheaded in Thailand: police], 28 November 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071201060200/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gHYaoq-uPXBWrI79BO2qUlAJKsUg |date=1 December 2007 }}</ref>
===2008=== According to the Thai Journalists Association, during the year 2008 alone there were over 500 attacks, resulting in more than 300 deaths in the four provinces where the insurgents operate.<ref name="Hrw.org">{{cite web|url=http://hrw.org/english/docs/2008/07/07/thaila19274.htm |title=Thailand: Beheadings, Burnings in Renewed Terror Campaign – Human Rights Watch |publisher=Hrw.org |accessdate=14 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080708212945/http://www.hrw.org/english/docs/2008/07/07/thaila19274.htm |archivedate=8 July 2008 }}</ref>
'''14 January''': Insurgents killed 9 soldiers in a bomb and shooting attack.<ref name=GS-2008-2008>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/thailand2-07.htm|title=Thailand Islamic Insurgency, 2007-2008|publisher=Global Security|date=|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref>
'''15 January''': A bombing left at least 39 people wounded in a market in Yala.<ref name=GS-2008-2008/>
'''24 January''': Militants fatally shot a teacher.<ref name=GS-2008-2008/>
'''4 February''': A bomb detonated outside an Islamic boarding school, one person was killed and 12 wounded. A second bombing wounded six persons.<ref name=GS-2008-2008/>
'''15 March''': A bombing occurred in the parking lot of hotel. Two persons were killed and 14 wounded in the incident.<ref name=GS-2008-2008/>
'''28 May''': Three soldiers and four rebels were killed in a series of incidents across the south.<ref name=GS-2008-2008/>
'''5 July''': Insurgents killed three cafe customers and injured four others.<ref name=GS-2008-2008/>
'''3 August''': Five bombs went off in the town of [[Songkhla]] injuring two persons. The same night, two bombs also exploded in Hat Yai, but caused no casualties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/040808_News/04Aug2008_news06.php |title=unk|accessdate=22 March 2015 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}</ref>
'''17 October''': One militant was killed and five others arrested.<ref name=GS-2008-2008/>
'''18 October''': Two persons were killed in drive-by shootings.<ref name=GS-2008-2008/>
'''4 November''': Two bombs exploded at a tea stall killing one person and wounded at least 71.<ref name=GS-2008-2008/>
'''5 December''': Four persons were killed by a bomb planted at a pharmacy.<ref name=GS-2008-2008/>
===2009=== '''31 January''': A grenade blast killed eight persons and injured 27 others outside a Buddhist temple.<ref name=GS-2009->{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/thailand2-09.htm|title=Thailand Islamic Insurgency, 2009- |publisher=Global Security|date=|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref>
'''20 February''': Two Thai soldiers were beheaded after a military convoy was ambushed. It was the second attack in the same month following the same pattern.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''13 March''': Militants killed three soldiers during an ambush in the Narathiwat Province.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''19 March''': A roadside bomb killed four army rangers in Pattani Province.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''7 June''': Insurgents killed two and injured 19 others in the Yi-ngo District of Narathiwat.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''8 June''': Rebel gunmen killed at least 10 and wounded 19 mosque visitors in Narathiwat Province's Hoh-I-Rong District.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''13 June''': Insurgents bombed a bus, killing one passenger and wounding 13 others in the center of Yala city. Additionally three people were killed and one wounded in drive-by incidents.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''18 June''': Security forces killed four militants during clashes in Yala Province.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''19 July''': Two people were killed in separate drive-by shootings in Yala and Narathiwat Provinces.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''20 July''': Rebels shot and killed a man in the Pattani Province.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''26 August''': A car bomb blast outside a restaurant wounded 26 people.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''2 September''': A number of drive-by shootings occurred in the provinces of Narathiwat, Pattani and Yala leaving eight dead. Security forces killed two militants in separate raids in Yala Province.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''3 September''': A bomb exploded in the city of Pattani killing one man and wounding 24 others.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''4 September''': A bomb detonated outside a restaurant, killing a policeman and wounding 12 other people.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''13 September''': Guerrillas killed five paramilitary troops in Yala Province.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''23 October''': A Muslim man was killed by gunmen while leaving a mosque after prayers in Yala Province. Also in Yala, a Muslim couple was shot in their home and the husband was killed. On the same day, the body of a Muslim man killed by insurgents was dumped on the side of the road in the Yarang District of Pattani Province.<ref name="LWJ"/>
'''28 October''': Guerrillas killed two civilians in separate drive-by attacks.<ref name=GS-2009-/>
'''1 November''': A teenage girl was shot and killed in Yala Province. A bomb exploded at the scene after the murder, wounding three police officers. The same day the police found the body of a man who had been handcuffed and murdered at a rice farm in the area.<ref name="LWJ"/>
'''12 November''': A Buddhist couple was shot and killed and five people were wounded in an explosion when they rushed to the scene following the murder that took place at a rice mill in Pattani Province.<ref name="LWJ"/>
'''8 December''': A bomb exploded at a local market in the Muang District of Narathiwat Province, killing two people and wounding nine others. The blast happened about 1 km from a hotel where Thai Prime Minister [[Abhisit Vejjajiva]] and his visiting Malaysian counterpart, [[Najib Razak]] were having lunch during a trip to the region that day. Sources say the bomb was hidden in the gas tank of a motorcycle.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/world/two-dead-in-bomb-ahead-of-leaders-visit-to-thai-south-20091208-kfov.html|title=Two dead in bomb ahead of leaders' visit to Thai south|work=Brisbane Times|accessdate=14 October 2014}}</ref>
'''10 December''': Three Buddhist women were killed by a remote-controlled bomb outside a restaurant in Narathiwat.<ref name="LLl">{{cite web|url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=82d_1260560561#7cR0fcoA2Oss1EXk.99|title=Live Leak list|publisher=|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
===2010=== '''2 January''': Three soldiers and three civilians were injured by roadside bombs in Yala at 10:00 in Bannang Sata District, Yala Province.<ref>''The Nation'', [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/30119596/6-injured-in-Yala-bomb-attack 6 injured in Yala Bomb Attack], 4 January 2010</ref>
'''13 January''': Mayo District chief Wirat Prasetto was seriously injured along with ten other civilians when a bomb detonated at a pier in Pattani Province. The bombing is blamed on Muslim insurgents. One person was killed in the explosion.<ref>[http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30064381 1 killed, 11 injured in Pattani explosion] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208045735/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/read.php?newsid=30064381 |date=8 February 2008 }}</ref>
Two villagers sitting at a tea shop in Narathiwat were murdered by gunmen on motorcycles.<ref name="LWJ">{{cite web|url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/tags/thailand/today-in/6#ixzz3GMTSHz00|title=Long War Journal|publisher=|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
'''1 April''': Suspected insurgents shot dead six villagers in Narathiwat province. Ten policemen and soldiers were also wounded when a roadside bomb exploded as they were travelling to the scene of the shootings.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6302EI20100401?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews&rpc=22&sp=true |title=Six killed in Thailand's insurgency-plagued south |agency=Reuters|date= 1 April 2010|accessdate=3 November 2011}}</ref>
'''22 May''': Two female villagers were killed in a drive-by shooting in Yala Province by suspected separatist militants.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/breakingnews/178835/two-villagers-shot-dead-in-yala |title=Two villagers shot dead in Yala |work=Bangkok Post |date=22 May 2010 |accessdate=3 November 2011 }}</ref>
'''28 May''': Two were killed and 52 injured in two bomb attacks in Yala.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v5/newsgeneral.php?id=501382 |title=Two Killed, 52 Injured In Two Bomb Attacks In Yala |work=Bernama |date=26 May 2010 |accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref>
'''8 September''': Police apprehended a [[Runda Kumpulan Kecil|RKK]] leader while he was in his house in [[Yala Province]]<ref>{{cite news|author=áÊ´§¤ÇÒÁ¤Ô´àËç¹ |url=http://www.bangkokbiznews.com/home/detail/politics/life/20100908/351941/%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%A7%E0%B8%9A%E0%B9%81%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%B3-RKK.html |title=ÃÇºá¡¹¹Ó RKK – ¡ÃØ§à·¾¸ØÃ¡Ô¨ ÍÍ¹äÅ¹ì |work=Bangkok Biz News |date= |accessdate=3 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928150416/http://www.bangkokbiznews.com/home/detail/politics/life/20100908/351941/%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%A7%E0%B8%9A%E0%B9%81%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%B3-RKK.html |archivedate=28 September 2011 }}</ref>
===2011=== '''27 January''': Insurgents killed a school teacher in Pattani Province.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2095306,00.html|title=The Real Victims in Southern Thailand's Insurgency|work=Time|date=28 September 2011|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
'''11 February''': Three people were shot and burned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brecorder.com/world/southeast-asia/2569-three-shot-burned-in-thai-south-police.html/ |title=Three shot, burned in Thai south: police |publisher=Brecorder.com |date=11 February 2011 |accessdate=3 November 2011}}</ref>
'''13 February''': A car bomb exploded which injured 18 people, civilians and soldiers, leaving seven hospitalised.<ref>''Bangkok Post'', [http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/221344/update-18-people-wounded-by-yala-car-bomb/ Update: Yala bomb wounds 18], 13 February 2011 {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Meanwhile, an insurgent was shot dead by soldiers.
'''22 March''': A man and two women were shot in a village of [[Narathiwat Province]] by about a dozen armed men. Police suspect the gunmen were Muslim insurgents who believed their victims were informants.<ref name="restive">{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/SEAsia/Story/STIStory_648280.html |title=Bomb follows killings in restive southern Thailand |work=Straits Times |date=23 March 2011 |accessdate=3 November 2011 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
'''23 March''': A roadside bomb went off in a village in Narathiwat when a truck carrying police arrived. None were wounded. The killings the night before may have been intended to lure security personnel to the scene to be attacked.<ref name="restive"/>
'''18 April''': A car bomb exploded in the business district of [[Yala Province|Yala]], killing a Thai paramilitary ranger and injuring 23 people including four other rangers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/SEAsia/Story/STIStory_658150.html/ |title=Bomb kills one, wounds 23 in restive Thai south |work=Straits Times |date=18 April 2011 |accessdate=3 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429094732/http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/SEAsia/Story/STIStory_658150.html |archivedate=29 April 2011 }}</ref>
'''3 May''': Two [[grenades]] were fired at Pattani Task Force 21 base, but did not hurt anyone.
'''11 May''': A bomb blast during a football match in [[Kapho District]] in [[Pattani Province]] killed four officers and wounded 13 others. Eight suspects were detained. In [[Yala Province]], two officers and two civilians were injured after a roadside bomb detonated in [[Meung District]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/security/236383/eight-held-over-fatal-bomb-blast-on-saturday |title=Eight held over fatal bomb blast on Saturday |work=Bangkok Post |date= |accessdate=3 November 2011 }}</ref>
'''14 May''': Four insurgents came and demanded money from a gas station. The wife of the owner refused, resulting in them shooting her and her sister. After that, the owner of the gas station came and shot dead one of the insurgents, causing the other three to retreat. The dead insurgent turned out to be a minor leader operating in the area who was wanted for 2009 Narathiwat bombings.
'''17 May''': A roadside bomb detonated in [[Yaha District]] in [[Yala Province]], killing two monks and seriously wounding two of their security escorts. More than 100 local [[Muslims]] gathered at the local mosque and condemned the violence.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/security/237370/bomb-kills-two-monks-in-yala |title=Bomb kills two monks in Yala |work=Bangkok Post |date=17 May 2011 |accessdate=3 November 2011 }}</ref>
'''18 May''':, A [[Thahan Phran]] from the 47th Regiment was shot and seriously wounded in Yala, Meung District<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/security/237455/ranger-wounded-in-yala-outpost-attack |title=Ranger wounded in Yala outpost attack |work=Bangkok Post |date=17 May 2011 |accessdate=3 November 2011 }}</ref>
'''20 May''': A 30-man [[Thahan Phran]] unit engaged and killed four insurgents in [[Ban Charupae]] in [[Than To District]] in Yala. They seized two [[AK-47]] assault rifles, a .38 calibre pistol and nine mobile phones. One of the dead was identified as [[Ma-ae Aphibalbae]], a key leader operating in the area who was sought for at least 28 alleged crimes, with a bounty of 2,000,000 baht.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/breakingnews/237985/update-4-militants-killed-in-yala-clash |title=Update: 4 militants killed in Yala clash |work=Bangkok Post |date=20 May 2011 |accessdate=3 November 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news
